Returns: true to indicate that the certificate authority exists in the user added certificate store, false otherwise.
isUserAddedCertificate(java.security.cer.Description: Checks whether a CA certificate is added by an user. Since @B_javax#net#ssl#X509TrustManager#checkServerTrusted_E@ may allow its parameter chain to chain up to user-added CA certificates, this method can be used to perform additional policies for user-added CA certificates.

isSameTrustConfiguration(java.lang.Strin.Description: Returns true if the TrustManager uses the same trust configuration for the provided hostnames.
isSameTrustConfiguration(java.lang.Strin.FullName: public boolean isSameTrustConfiguration (String hostname1, String hostname2)

Returns: the properly ordered chain used for verification as a list of X509Certificates.
Throws: if the chain does not verify correctly.
checkServerTrusted(java.security.cert.X5.Description: Verifies the given certificate chain. See @B_javax#net#ssl#X509TrustManager#checkServerTrusted_E@ for a description of the chain and authType parameters. The final parameter, host, should be the hostname of the server.
checkServerTrusted(java.security.cert.X5.FullName: public List<X509Certificate> checkServerTrusted (X509Certificate[] chain, String authType, String host)

Parameters: X509TrustManager: A @B_javax#net#ssl#X509TrustManager_E@ as returned by TrustManagerFactory.getInstance();
Throws: If tm is an unsupported TrustManager type.

ClassDesc: X509TrustManager wrapper exposing Android-added features. The checkServerTrusted method allows callers to perform additional verification of certificate chains after they have been successfully verified by the platform.
